questions.question: What is an atom?
questions.answer: Atom is the smallest particle of an element that takes part in chemical reactions. It consists of nucleus and electrons revolving around it.

questions.question: What are sub-atomic particles?
questions.answer: Particles present inside the atom are called sub-atomic particles. They are electrons, protons and neutrons.

questions.question: What is nucleus?
questions.answer: Nucleus is the central part of atom containing protons and neutrons. It has positive charge and most of the atomic mass.

questions.question: Why is nucleus positively charged?
questions.answer: Because nucleus contains protons which carry positive charge. Neutrons have no charge.

questions.question: Where are electrons found?
questions.answer: Electrons revolve around nucleus in fixed shells or orbits. They are negatively charged particles.

questions.question: What is atomic number?
questions.answer: Atomic number is the number of protons present in nucleus of atom. It determines the identity of element.

questions.question: What is mass number?
questions.answer: Mass number is total number of protons and neutrons in nucleus. It represents atomic mass.

questions.question: Why electrons do not fall into nucleus?
questions.answer: Electrons move in fixed energy levels. As long as they remain in stable orbit, they do not lose energy.

questions.question: What is electronic configuration?
questions.answer: Arrangement of electrons in different shells around nucleus is called electronic configuration.

questions.question: What is valence shell?
questions.answer: The outermost shell of an atom is called valence shell. It determines chemical properties of element.

questions.question: What are valence electrons?
questions.answer: Electrons present in valence shell are called valence electrons. They take part in chemical bonding.

questions.question: What is valency?
questions.answer: Valency is combining capacity of an element. It depends on number of electrons lost, gained or shared.

questions.question: Why noble gases have valency zero?
questions.answer: Their valence shell is completely filled. Hence they do not lose or gain electrons.

questions.question: What is duplet rule?
questions.answer: Atoms with two electrons in valence shell are stable. Hydrogen follows duplet rule.

questions.question: What is octet rule?
questions.answer: Atoms tend to complete eight electrons in valence shell to become stable. Most elements follow octet rule.

questions.question: What are isotopes?
questions.answer: Atoms of same element having same atomic number but different mass numbers are called isotopes.

questions.question: Why isotopes show same chemical properties?
questions.answer: Chemical properties depend on electronic configuration which is same for isotopes.

questions.question: Why isotopes have different mass?
questions.answer: Because number of neutrons is different in isotopes, which changes mass number.

questions.question: Give one use of C-14.
questions.answer: Carbon-14 is used to determine age of fossils and ancient objects by carbon dating method.

questions.question: Give one medical use of isotopes.
questions.answer: Cobalt-60 is used in treatment of cancer and Iodine-131 is used to treat thyroid disease.

questions.question: What is nuclear fission?
questions.answer: Splitting of heavy nucleus into smaller nuclei releasing large energy is called nuclear fission.

questions.question: What is chain reaction?
questions.answer: In fission, released neutrons cause further fission of nuclei, producing continuous reaction called chain reaction.

questions.question: What is nuclear reactor?
questions.answer: It is a device that controls nuclear fission to produce electricity safely.

questions.question: What is role of moderator?
questions.answer: Moderator slows down fast neutrons so that controlled fission can continue.

questions.question: What is role of control rods?
questions.answer: They absorb extra neutrons and control speed of chain reaction in reactor.

questions.question: Why uranium-235 is used as fuel?
questions.answer: U-235 easily undergoes fission and releases large amount of energy.

questions.question: What is nuclear energy?
questions.answer: Energy released from nucleus during fission or fusion is called nuclear energy.

questions.question: Why nuclear energy is powerful?
questions.answer: Very small amount of fuel releases huge energy compared to chemical reactions.

questions.question: Why safety is important in reactors?
questions.answer: Uncontrolled reaction can cause explosion and radiation hazards, so strict safety is required.

questions.question: What is radiation?
questions.answer: Radiation is emission of high-energy particles or waves from unstable nuclei.

questions.question: Why radiation is harmful to humans?
questions.answer: Radiation damages body cells and DNA, causing serious diseases like cancer.

questions.question: What is half-life of isotope?
questions.answer: Time taken by half quantity of radioactive substance to decay is called half-life.

questions.question: Why isotopes are used in industry?
questions.answer: They help detect leaks, measure thickness and sterilize medical equipment.

questions.question: What is atomic stability?
questions.answer: Atoms are stable when their valence shell is completely filled with electrons.

questions.question: Why atoms form bonds?
questions.answer: To achieve stable electronic configuration by completing octet or duplet.

questions.question: Why hydrogen is unique?
questions.answer: It can lose or gain one electron and follow duplet rule, unlike other elements.

questions.question: Why atomic mass of electron is neglected?
questions.answer: Its mass is very small compared to proton and neutron, so contribution is negligible.

questions.question: Why proton and neutron called nucleons?
questions.answer: Because both are present inside nucleus of atom.

questions.question: What is atomic notation?
questions.answer: It shows atomic number and mass number of element using symbols A and Z.

questions.question: Why nucleus is very small?
questions.answer: Most of atom is empty space and nucleus occupies very tiny region at center.

questions.question: Why most alpha particles passed through foil?
questions.answer: Because atom is mostly empty space, allowing particles to pass without deflection.

questions.question: Why few particles deflected back?
questions.answer: They hit dense and positively charged nucleus and bounced back.

questions.question: Why Rutherford model failed?
questions.answer: It could not explain stability of atom and fixed energy levels of electrons.

questions.question: How Bohr model solved stability problem?
questions.answer: It proposed fixed orbits where electrons do not lose energy.

questions.question: What happens when electron jumps shell?
questions.answer: Energy is absorbed or released as light depending on direction of jump.

questions.question: Why sodium lamp gives yellow light?
questions.answer: Due to excitation of sodium electrons which emit yellow light when returning to lower energy.

questions.question: Why atomic number is more important than mass number?
questions.answer: Atomic number determines element identity and chemical properties.

questions.question: Why different elements exist?
questions.answer: Because atoms have different number of protons and electronic configurations.

questions.question: What is artificial radioactivity?
questions.answer: It is produced by bombarding stable nuclei with particles to make them radioactive.

questions.question: Why radioactive waste is dangerous?
questions.answer: It emits radiation for long time and can damage living organisms.

questions.question: Why isotopes are chemically similar but physically different?
questions.answer: Electronic configuration is same but mass differs due to neutrons.

questions.question: Why heavy elements are radioactive?
questions.answer: Large nucleus becomes unstable and releases energy to become stable.

questions.question: Why nuclear fusion not used in reactors?
questions.answer: Fusion requires extremely high temperature which is difficult to maintain.

questions.question: What is fusion?
questions.answer: Fusion is combining of light nuclei to form heavier nucleus releasing energy.

questions.question: Where does fusion occur naturally?
questions.answer: Fusion occurs in sun where high temperature and pressure exist.

questions.question: Why nuclear power plants are built near water?
questions.answer: Water is required for cooling reactor and producing steam.

questions.question: Why lead shielding is used?
questions.answer: Lead blocks radiation and protects workers from harmful effects.

questions.question: Why nuclear energy is controversial?
questions.answer: It produces dangerous waste and accidents can cause serious disasters.

questions.question: Why isotopes are used in agriculture?
questions.answer: They help study nutrient absorption and improve crop production.

questions.question: Why atomic theory changed over time?
questions.answer: New experiments revealed new facts, leading to improved atomic models.

questions.question: Why scientific models change?
questions.answer: They change when better experimental evidence becomes available.

questions.question: What is importance of isotopes in science?
questions.answer: They help in medical diagnosis, research and industrial testing.

questions.question: Why is neutron necessary in nucleus?
questions.answer: Neutrons reduce repulsion between protons and stabilize nucleus.

questions.question: Why electrons are arranged in shells?
questions.answer: Shells represent energy levels where electrons remain stable.

questions.question: Why valency determines chemical behavior?
questions.answer: It decides how atoms combine with others to form compounds.

questions.question: Why outer shell is most important?
questions.answer: Because chemical reactions involve only valence electrons.

questions.question: Why isotopes are useful in tracing?
questions.answer: Their radiation can be easily detected, helping in tracking movement.

questions.question: Why atomic structure is important to study?
questions.answer: It explains properties of matter and chemical reactions.

questions.question: Why electrons have negative charge?
questions.answer: Because they carry excess negative electric charge by nature.

questions.question: Why protons are positive?
questions.answer: Protons carry positive electric charge equal and opposite to electron.

questions.question: Why isotopes used in sterilization?
questions.answer: Radiation kills bacteria and germs on medical instruments.

questions.question: Why radioactive decay is random?
questions.answer: It cannot be predicted which atom will decay at what time.

questions.question: Why nuclear energy is called clean energy?
questions.answer: It does not release smoke or carbon dioxide during power generation.

questions.question: Why handling radioactive material is risky?
questions.answer: Exposure can damage tissues and cause long-term health problems.

questions.question: Why stable isotopes do not emit radiation?
questions.answer: Their nuclei are balanced and do not need to release energy.

questions.question: Why atoms of same element are similar?
questions.answer: They have same atomic number and same electronic configuration.

questions.question: Why chemical reactions do not affect nucleus?
questions.answer: Chemical reactions involve electrons only, nucleus remains unchanged.

questions.question: Why nuclear reactions release more energy?
questions.answer: Because mass is converted into energy according to Einstein’s equation.

questions.question: Why electron is called elementary particle?
questions.answer: It cannot be broken into smaller charged particles.

questions.question: Why proton number defines element?
questions.answer: Different proton numbers mean different elements with unique properties.

questions.question: Why hydrogen isotope deuterium is heavy?
questions.answer: It contains one proton and one neutron, increasing its mass.

questions.question: Why radioactive isotopes must be handled carefully?
questions.answer: They emit harmful radiation that can damage living cells.

questions.question: Why atomic models are needed?
questions.answer: They help visualize structure of atom and explain experimental results.

questions.question: Why matter is electrically neutral?
questions.answer: Number of electrons equals number of protons in atoms.

questions.question: Why positive and negative charges attract?
questions.answer: Electrostatic force causes opposite charges to attract each other.

questions.question: Why mass of nucleus is high?
questions.answer: Because protons and neutrons are heavy particles compared to electrons.

questions.question: Why atomic mass is not whole number?
questions.answer: Due to presence of isotopes and average mass calculation.

questions.question: Why electron capacity increases in outer shells?
questions.answer: Because shell number increases and energy level is higher.

questions.question: Why isotopes are unstable?
questions.answer: Imbalance of neutrons and protons makes nucleus unstable.

questions.question: Why radioactive decay cannot be stopped?
questions.answer: It is natural process that occurs without external control.

questions.question: Why nuclear weapons are dangerous?
questions.answer: They release massive energy and harmful radiation causing destruction.

questions.question: Why atomic energy is important today?
questions.answer: It provides large amount of electricity with less fuel consumption.

questions.question: Why isotopes help in diagnosis?
questions.answer: Their radiation helps detect internal organ problems.

questions.question: Why heavy nuclei split easily?
questions.answer: Large repulsive force between protons makes them unstable.

questions.question: Why nuclear waste needs safe storage?
questions.answer: It remains radioactive for long time and can harm environment.

questions.question: Why atoms are mostly empty space?
questions.answer: Distance between nucleus and electrons is very large compared to nucleus size.

questions.question: Why discovery of nucleus was important?
questions.answer: It showed that positive charge and mass are concentrated at center.

questions.question: Why atomic structure affects properties?
questions.answer: Arrangement of electrons decides reactivity and bonding behavior.

questions.question: Why isotopes useful despite radiation risk?
questions.answer: Their benefits in medicine and industry outweigh risks when used safely.

questions.question: Give conclusion of Inside the Atom chapter.
questions.answer: Atom consists of nucleus and electrons, and its structure explains chemical and nuclear phenomena used in science and technology.
